text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Added internal controls sections numbered IRM 11.3.12.1 through 11.3.12.1.4 and renumbered subsequent sections accordingly. Titled IRM 11.3.12.1 Program Scope and Objectives, to properly reﬂect the information communicated in this subsection. Information from prior section 11.3.12.1, Purpose, was incorporated into this updated section. Also included important information to conform to the new internal and management control standards under the following titles:
a. IRM
, Authority - Added legal authorities pertaining to designation of documents. b. IRM
, Responsibilities - This IRM applies to all IRS personnel. c. IRM
, Terms/Deﬁnitions/Acronyms - Compiled a list of frequently used terms and acronyms pertaining to the designation of documents. d. IRM
, Related Resources - Added related resources applicable to the designation of documents.

Updated various sections of the IRM, as applicable, to reﬂect changes to the Freedom of Act instituting a harm standard that must be applied when considering the withholding of from public release. Included information throughout stating that authorized officials making a determination to designate a record, must maintain documentation which justiﬁes how the demonstrable harm standard applies to the designated records. See IRM 11.3.13, Freedom of Information Act, for additional information on the FOIA harm standard.

Added information throughout to emphasize the designation of a record is made by the authorized official identiﬁed in Delegation Order 11-1 found in IRM 1.2.49 and that authorized officials must maintain documentation to justify the designation.
Added new Note to (4) and (5) of IRM 11.3.12.2, The Intent of Designation, to clarify that the “Limited Official Use” legend is historical and should not be used to designate a record.
Added IRM 11.3.12.2.2, Official Use Only (OUO) Decision Tool, providing examples of OUO information and examples of information that does not qualify as OUO.
Changed title of IRM 11.3.12.3 from Guidelines for Designation to Guidelines for Administrative Controls.
Changed title of IRM 11.3.12.3 from Guidelines for Designation to Guidelines for Administrative

Changed the title of IRM 11.3.12.3.1, Printed Materials, to Published Materials and removed (1), (2) and (9). Added new (5) to provide information on the Form 1767, Publication Services Requisition and added a reference in (8) to the Form 13709, Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) Checklist for Internal Management Documents and Training Materials.
Added new (2) and removed (4) from IRM 11.3.12.5.1, Authority for Special Releases. Subsequent paragraphs were renumbered accordingly.
Obsoleted IRM sections 11.3.12.7 through IRM 11.3.12.9. Subsequent subsection was renumbered accordingly.

Added new IRM 11.3.12.7, Disclosure Requirements Under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). Also added new IRM 11.3.12.7.1, Transparency of Instructions to Staff, detailing the transparency guidelines surrounding “instructions to staff that affect a member of the public,” IRM 11.3.12.7.2, Complying with FOIA Requirements for Instructions to Staff, discussing how IRS complies with the transparency guidelines, and IRM 11.3.12.7.3, E-FOIA Criteria for Instructions to Staff, discussing FOIA rules requiring the proactive disclosure of “instructions to staff.”

Made editorial changes throughout to update IRM/statute/organizational references and terms. Web and citation references were added/updated throughout to make the text easier to research in electronic media.
This material supersedes IRM 11.3.12 dated October 30,
All Operating Divisions and Functions.
RESOURCES
The Disclosure and Privacy Knowledge Base can be found at: https://portal.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/vl003/ pages/default.aspx
Phyllis T. Grimes, Director, Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards (GLDS).

of Documents

) Purpose: This section provides procedures for designating certain intended for internal use as Official Use Only (OUO) and guidance for and mining their release. This section also contains instructions and restrictions the use of personal identiﬁers in printed materials and the inclusion of information in instructions. (
) The only designation available for labeling documents intended for internal use is Official Use Only (OUO). (
) These instructions do not apply to documents classiﬁed for national purposes under Executive Order
and designated as “Top Secret”, “Secret”, or “Conﬁdential”. For instructions relating to materials designated national security or foreign policy purposes, see IRM
, National Information. (
) These instructions also do not apply to documents with any label outside Internal Revenue Service (IRS). (
) This section also contains instructions and restrictions on the use of identiﬁers and return information in printed or published materials. (
) Instructions contained in IRM
, Freedom of Information Act Reading Room Operations, and IRM
, Freedom of Information Act are related to this section. A reading of those sections may be helpful in under- standing and providing perspective for the instructions in this section. (
) See IRM

, Physical Security Program, for instructions establishing the minimum standards required to administratively control, transmit, store, and ultimately destroy material determined to require administrative control nation) following instructions contained in this section. (
) Audience: These instructions apply to IRS employees, including IRS Chief Counsel employees and contractors, working with non-national security documents intended for internal use. (
) Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (

) Program Owner: Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards under Office of Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) is the owner with authority to issue guidance on the standards for the control of IRS records. (
) The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA),
USC §

, requires agencies to make available to the public information contained in agency records, for matters identiﬁed as exempt from disclosure under provisions of the Agencies make determinations about whether to release, or to exempt from release, under the FOIA solely on the basis of FOIA criteria and consider- ations. The fact that something is OUO, does not change the basis upon agencies must make FOIA determinations. Agencies may determine that certain documents are exempt from release under FOIA that also qualify are marked as OUO, but the OUO status does not cause or inﬂuence that termination. (
) When designating OUO, offices should clear proposed designations of tion being released to the public, through the Office of Disclosure to make (

Instructions contained in IRM 11.3.7, Freedom of Information Act Reading Room Operations, and IRM 11.3.13, Freedom of Information Act are closely related to this section. A reading of those sections may be helpful in under- standing and providing perspective for the instructions in this section.
Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy.

determination that a record or relevant portions of the record are exempt from the FOIA and would present a harm to IRS operations or to personal privacy interests at the time of designation. Authorized officials making a determination to designate a record, must maintain documentation which justiﬁes how the FOIA demonstrable harm standard applies to the designated records.
FOIA demonstrable harm standard applies to the designated records. (
) The Privacy Act of
USC §
a(e)(

), requires agencies maintaining systems of records to: • “...establish appropriate administrative, technical, and physical safe- guards to ensure the security and conﬁdentiality of records and to protect against any anticipated threats or hazards to their security or integrity which could result in substantial harm, embarrassment, incon- venience, or unfairness to any individual on whom information is maintained.” (
USC §

requires that: • “Government publications, except those determined by their issuing components to be required for official use only or for strictly tion or operational purposes which have no public interest or educational value and publications classiﬁed for reasons of national security, shall be made available to depository libraries through the fa- cilities of the Superintendent of Documents for public information.” (
) TD P

, “Treasury Security Manual” provides the authority to designate information not entitled to protection in the interest of national security under appropriate Executive Order, but which requires protection. (
) The officials authorized to administratively control and designate IRS records as “Official Use Only” are found in Delegation Order
, as published in
) The Director, Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards (GLDS) is executive responsible for the Disclosure program. (
) The Associate Director, Disclosure is the program manager for Disclosure. (

) Disclosure Office managers and management officials are responsible for assessing, applying, implementing and communicating aspects of the trative control of records that fall under the purview of the Freedom of Information Act, the Privacy Act and other disclosure laws. (
) IRS and Disclosure Office employees with responsibilities to create or records are responsible to protect and control access to and dissemination of those records, as appropriate. (
) Delegation Order
, found in IRM
, names the officials authorized to approve “Official Use Only” designations. (
) All employees and contractors have responsibility for ensuring IRS records (hard copy and electronic) are appropriately managed, retained, and archived in accordance with IRM
, Records and Information Management series records retention and disposition requirements before documents can be destroyed. Refer to Document
, IRS Records Control Schedules (RCS), for the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA)-approved IRS records disposition to prevent unauthorized/unlawful destruction of records.
“...establish appropriate administrative, technical, and physical safe

guards to ensure the security and conﬁdentiality of records and to protect against any anticipated threats or hazards to their security or integrity which could result in substantial harm, embarrassment, incon
venience, or unfairness to any individual on whom information is maintained.”

Director, Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for the Disclosure program.
Refer to Document 12829, General Records Schedules (GRS), for the NARA- issued disposal authorizations for temporary administrative records common to all Federal agencies.
The tables below list commonly used terms, deﬁnitions and acronyms used throughout this IRM section.

Sensitive information made available to the public that meets a Freedom of Information Act exemption and where there is a reason- able expectation that disclosure would harm tax administration or IRS operations or that disclosure is speciﬁcally prohibited by law

of form or characteristics, made or received by a Federal agency under Federal law or in connection with the transaction of public business and preserved or appropriate for preservation by that agency or its legitimate successor as evidence of the organization, functions, policies, decisions, procedures, operations, or other activities of the United States Government or because of the infor- mational value of data in them. ) A major intention for designating a record “Official Use Only” is to prevent automatic distribution to the public of materials otherwise exempt from the FOIA where disclosure carries a reasonable expectation of harm to a ment interest or to a personal privacy interest. (
) The designation system promotes uniformity by reducing the likelihood of holding a record in one office while releasing it in another. (
) Identifying a small portion of IRS printed materials as “Official Use Only” tates the ready release to the public of printed materials that are not designated as “Official Use Only”. (

) The legends “Limited Official Use” and “Official Use Only” should act to employees that the release of a record is prohibited, except by an official acting in accordance with the provisions of this section or other zation. Note: The legend of “Limited Official Use” is historical and should no longer be used to designate a record. See IRM
)c) for additional tion. (

) The legends “Limited Official Use” and “Official Use Only” are internal tions that have no effect with regard to any member of the public who may have received such records. Note: The legend of “Limited Official Use” is historical and should no longer be used to designate a record. See IRM
)c) for additional tion. (
) This section also includes restrictions to prevent the abuse of over and provisions for removing the designations of records containing that no longer requires protection.

A major intention for designating a record “Official Use Only” is to prevent automatic distribution to the public of materials otherwise exempt from the FOIA where disclosure carries a reasonable expectation of harm to a ment interest or to a personal privacy interest. The designation system promotes uniformity by reducing the likelihood of holding a record in one office while releasing it in another. Identifying a small portion of IRS printed materials as “Official Use Only” tates the ready release to the public of printed materials that are not designated as “Official Use Only”. The legends “Limited Official Use” and “Official Use Only” should act to employees that the release of a record is prohibited, except by an official acting in accordance with the provisions of this section or other zation.
Disclosure of Official (
) The limited distribution of some IRS documents, and the normal of IRS ﬁles as required by law to prevent unauthorized disclosures, may administrative “Official Use Only” designation unnecessary. (
) Use the designation “Official Use Only” on the following types of records. a. Published materials intended for internal use. See IRM

, Published Materials. b. Guidance from Headquarters officials to ﬁeld officials containing tions that would be subject to a FOIA exemption and where disclosure carries a reasonable expectation of harm to a protected interest. c. Documents formerly designated “Limited Official Use” that continue to subject to a FOIA exemption and where disclosure carries a expectation of harm to a protected interest. d. Tolerance and criteria portions of implementing agreements, Memoran- dums of Understanding, or their equivalent for exchange of tax returns and return information with state or federal agencies. (

) The absence of an “Official Use Only” designation from any record not described above does not indicate that the record may be automatically released to the public but merely means that its releasability depends upon other factors. (
) The “Official Use Only” designation shall be effective only when applied in cordance with this section, by officials authorized by Delegation Order
, found in IRM

, and with the concurrence of the Office of Disclosure such concurrence is required. Authorized officials making a determination to designate a record, must maintain documentation which justiﬁes how the de- monstrable harm standard applies to the designated records. (

) IRS no longer uses former designations such as “For Official IRS Use Only”, “For Official Use Only”, or “Limited Official Use”. Consider any record these designations or anything other than “Official Use Only” to be “Official Only.” (
) The use of pseudo-designations such as “internal use only” or “eyes only” no official standing. Treat records marked with pseudo-designations as if were not designated. (
) Do not mark records “Official Use Only”, without the approval of an official thorized under Delegation Order
, found in IRM
Authorized making a determination to designate a record, must maintain documentation which justiﬁes how the demonstrable harm standard applies to the records. (

) OUO Deﬁnition: ″Official Use Only” information is sensitive information, available to the public, that meets a Freedom of Information Act exemption (OUO) and where there is a reasonable expectation that disclosure would harm tax administration or IRS operations or that disclosure is prohibited by law. (
) OUO Examples:
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

The limited distribution of some IRS documents, and the normal safeguarding of IRS ﬁles as required by law to prevent unauthorized disclosures, may make administrative “Official Use Only” designation unnecessary.

OUO Deﬁnition: ″Official Use Only” information is sensitive information, made available to the public, that meets a Freedom of Information Act exemption and where there is a reasonable expectation that disclosure would harm tax administration or IRS operations or that disclosure is prohibited by law.

) These guidelines are intended to assist officials making recommendations for the administrative control of records covered by this section. (

) Aside from the obvious requirement that all actions must be strictly in accor- dance with all applicable provisions of law, these are guidelines and not rules that must be followed in every instance. Apply them in light of the speciﬁc cir- cumstances involved in any situation. (

) The overall objective is to make available to the public the greatest amount information whenever possible. Do not apply these guidelines in a manner would produce a result contrary to this objective. (

) The Freedom of Information Act requires the federal government to make its records available to the public unless the records are subject to one of the emptions provided by the Act and the agency is able to articulate a expectation of harm to a protectable interest. (
) The FOIA Improvement Act of

revised the FOIA to limit withholding the FOIA to situations where agencies reasonably foresee disclosure would harm an interest protected by an exemption in the statute or where the sure is prohibited by law. Officials evaluating material for designation or for removal of previous designations should be alert to opportunities to disclose circumstances where the disclosure is not prohibited by law and there is no reasonable expectation of harm even though a FOIA exemption may apply. Doing so will permit IRS to operate as transparently as possible without harming any valid interest. (

) Do not designate materials simply because they may be subject to tation, because there is no apparent public beneﬁt to their release, to avoid embarrassment, or to hide instances of errors or wrong-doing by IRS officials or employees. (

) If information is generally known, although not published, that does not sarily mean public release of the information would not interfere with IRS operations or activities. A limited disclosure previously made by IRS will not cause the IRS to forego the defense of such materials, but a substantial bution may no longer have its protection defended.
These guidelines are intended to assist officials making recommendations for the administrative control of records covered by this section.

The designation of published documents is part of the preparation process. Include the “Official Use Only” designation during the publication process rather than applying it subsequently. Omission of the “Official Use Only” desig
nation may result in erroneous public distribution of records, as some may incorrectly presume that the absence of a designation means the record is intended for public release.

11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

or other clearance document. (
) Authors must generally obtain a specialized review from the Disclosure for any “Official Use Only” controls. (

) If all of the material in a procedural guidance document merits protection, control label “Official Use Only” must be shown on each page of the The document may have attachments that are designated, partially or not designated on their own merits. (
) An undesignated document may have attachments that are designated or partially designated. Mark each page of such documents “Note: all or some the attachments are designated Official Use Only.” (

) If a procedural guidance or training document includes both protected tion and meaningful information that is not appropriate for protection, the content must be evaluated on a content basis. Any protected content will a # sign before and after the content designated. All pages must carry the ignation “Any text marked with a # is Official Use Only.” Note: This designation will be shown on each page, even though the speciﬁc may not contain any protected material. (

) If some pages in a memorandum are partially designated using the symbol and other pages require protection for their complete content, the latter should carry the designation “any text marked with a # is Official Use Only” and the symbol # should mark the beginning and ending of content on pages. (
) Disclosure staff processing FOIA requests for procedural documents that subject to this section must consider the appropriate FOIA exemptions in making a release determination. See IRM
, Freedom of Information (

) Disclosure Managers should not deny FOIA requests for materials subject this section solely based on their designation as “Official Use Only,” but apply any appropriate FOIA exemptions where release of the materials a reasonable expectation of harm. If the records no longer meet the standards under the FOIA, managers may work with the owner of the to remove any OUO designation. (

a. Mark each page with the designation “Any text marked with a # is Official Use Only,” regardless of whether the particular page contains any protected material or not. b. Identify protected material with the symbol # placed before and after the text. c. For public use, the issuance may be posted to www.irs.gov in redacted form.
Note: The originator must inform Media and Publications on Form 1767 to prepare a redacted electronic version for www.irs.gov or use an equivalent process to
redact OUO content. The public version will have all text marked with the # sign removed and replaced with some clear marking or symbol that shows the extent of the redactions.
The designation of data processing materials as “Official Use Only” generally requires review through the Office of Disclosure.

Due to the highly technical nature of their content, some data processing materials, such as Computer Program Books and Systems Acceptability Testing drafts may be designated by officials authorized by Delegation Order 11-1 without the Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure review. Au-

) The designation of data processing materials serves three objectives. a. To protect information in data processing instructions designated OUO other offices. b. To protect information that could be used to alter ﬁling practices or the payment of taxes by protecting tolerances, criteria, details of computer analysis, and the speciﬁc identities of items that may or may not be transcribed. c. To prevent interference in computer processes for purposes of fraud or disruption by protecting data processing codes, routines, and safety security provisions. (

) When proposing OUO designations, the intent should be to deny public to materials and listings of data processing codes or system security proce- dures where IRS is able to articulate a reasonable expectation of harm to operations resulting from disclosure. Designation should not be given to mation that does not clearly undermine the integrity of the computer system itself (e.g., most of Document
, IRS Processing Codes and Information available at www.irs.gov). (

) Do not remove every mention of an otherwise innocuous code from every public document in which it might appear, since occasional disclosures of limited information would not likely permit a reconstruction of the extensive nature necessary to threaten computer processes. Moreover, individual re- questers are generally entitled to receive records that pertain to them and to receive an adequate explanation of their content. It is current Service policy provide the public instructions for reading transcripts when such transcripts not self-evident. (

) Training materials may require administrative control for three reasons. a. They repeat controlled procedural guidance or data processing tion and thus require administrative control to protect those materials. b. They may include original information not appearing elsewhere, that requires administrative control because a FOIA exemption applies and there is a reasonable expectation of harm to an IRS or to a personal privacy interest if the information were disclosed. c. They require administrative control to protect the integrity of the process.

a. To protect information in data processing instructions designated OUO other offices. b. , IRS Processing Codes and Information is available at www.irs.gov). Do not remove every mention of an otherwise innocuous code from every public document in which it might appear, since occasional disclosures of limited information would not likely permit a reconstruction of the extensive nature necessary to threaten computer processes. Moreover, individual re- questers are generally entitled to receive records that pertain to them and to receive an adequate explanation of their content. It is current Service policy provide the public instructions for reading transcripts when such transcripts not self-evident.

Note: Instructor Guides and related materials may be administratively controlled prevent students from obtaining advance knowledge of test questions and answers, discussion problems, and other training techniques whose effec- tiveness would be diminished if known. (
) Training materials proposed for administrative control normally require the currence of Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure. (

) The following types of administrative control may be used with training materials: a. If all or most of the material is administratively controlled, the entire training publication will be designated “Official Use Only.” This designa- tion will be shown on the cover of the document and printed at the bottom of each page. Also, place the symbol # at the beginning and of the text on each page. b. If protecting only certain chapters or units, apply the control label Use Only,” to all pages in those chapters or units. The cover of the document should contain a statement to the effect that “Note: --- are designated ’’Official Use Only’’”. Also, place the symbol # at the beginning and end of the text on each page administratively controlled. c. If protecting certain pages within a chapter, apply the control label “Official Use Only” to only those pages. The cover of the document should contain a statement to the effect that “Page(s) --- are ‘Official Use Only’”. Also, place the symbol # at the beginning and end the text on each page administratively controlled. d. If protecting certain text within a page, place the symbol # before and after the text. Indicate in the page footer, “Any text marked with a # is ’’Official Use Only.’’” The cover of the document should contain a statement to the effect, “Text marked with # --- is ’’Official Use Only.’’” (
) Special circumstances may require adaptations to “Official Use Only” tions, such as those indicated for training materials in IRM
), Training Materials.. (
) Adaptations could include practices such as having all “Official Use Only” material separated below a line, printed in a different color or different style type, or printed in a shaded area. (
) Documents using adaptations require designation as “Official Use Only” on their cover page and a clear explanation on each page to differentiate the protected and public portions of the text. (
) Adaptations of the “Official Use Only” designation require review through the Office of Disclosure. (

) When reviewing a controlled document that has not been released to the public, consider whether the original control was proper. The material may have been controlled in error and the administrative control may now be removed. (
) Even a document correctly controlled at the outset may warrant a removal of the control because of changing Freedom of Information Act standards. Over Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) A Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request for a document is equivalent to request to remove a record’s administrative control. (
) The release of a document to a member of the public will generally constitute the removal of that record’s administrative control. (
) IRS employees may rely upon a formal release to the public of a controlled record under the FOIA as authority for any subsequent releases of the document. (

) The removal of a record’s administrative control does not require solely to produce a version free of the “Official Use Only” designation if IRS needs do not otherwise require re-issuance of the document. However, any future editions of the record that may be produced should no longer carry the “Official Use Only” designation. (

) Generally, do not issue instructions to recipients of controlled records to the “Official Use Only” designation when it is no longer applicable because such documents may be widely distributed through IRS, rendering impractical. (

) Many materials designated “Official Use Only” are subjected to a continuous review process to ensure they are current, and are periodically updated and republished. a. Any review updating and reissuing a OUO record should consider the continuing need for administrative control. b. Do not designate records “Official Use Only” merely because a prior edition was designated. Evaluate each record on its own merits in dance with current standards. (

) Prior to the issuance of these instructions, it was difficult to identify instances where controlled material contained statutorily protected return information. Therefore recipients were not always aware of the level of protection these materials required. (

) Accordingly, these instructions provide the following guidelines: • Avoid including return information in published materials • Designate any materials that include such information for distribution only within Treasury • Limit their distribution within Treasury to employees with an official “need to know” basis and • Speciﬁcally label such information whenever it occurs in published matter (

) The following are examples of names that may appear in printed materials some other context and are not subject to protection: • Manufacturers of equipment used by IRS • Issuers of money orders • Names of return preparer ﬁrms requiring special processing • Names of ﬁrms that serve notices of levies or other legal documents behalf of the IRS (

) The appearance of identities and return information in published materials should be avoided. If it is impossible or highly problematic to avoid the use such information, the distribution of such materials must be controlled within Treasury and an attempt should be made to mitigate the problem by limiting the amount of information included. (

) Whenever possible, the use of actual return information should be avoided creating ﬁctional examples of similar situations that contain neither the of the taxpayer nor any information that could be considered attributable to a particular taxpayer. , Learning and Education - Learning and Policy. (

) If ﬁctional examples are not appropriate, consider using composite examples which components are drawn from ten or more cases (in a national or state level example), rendering the result as statistical data precluding the tion of any taxpayer. Such examples would not require any designation. (
) The Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS) function can provide guidance in formulating such statistical compilations. (

) In the absence of any other alternative, actual case data may be used provided the materials are distributed only to those having a need to know, should be designation as OUO. a. Disclosure of Official Note: It is important to realize that minimizing the information presented and omitting identifying factors does not remove the statutory protection of information. Such information must be designated OUO. (

) In choosing actual cases for presentation, select the best example for the intended purpose while avoiding information pertaining to persons of or prominence. Exercise restraint to avoid including anecdotal material that does not contribute to the effectiveness of the example. (
) See IRM
, Disclosure to Federal Officers and Employees for Tax Ad- ministration Purposes, for a complete discussion regarding use of tax data printed materials and training. (

) IRS published materials such as manual instructions and training guides, whether administratively controlled or not, sometimes require the use of ﬁctional names and addresses in illustrations or hypothetical discussions. Select or construct names and addresses in a manner to avoid to IRS or harm or offense to individuals, businesses or communities. Note: See IRM
, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process, IRM
, Learning and Education - Learning and Education Policy, and IRM
, Privacy Policy, for reference and for deﬁnition of PII. (

) Names and addresses that may not be used include: a. Any name or address that may easily be mistaken for or associated a real person or place. b. Any name or address that may be associated with any prominent living or dead, from the political, scientiﬁc, entertainment, sports, or ﬁelds. c. Any name or address that may have an ethnic or racial identiﬁcation. Note: A name having an ethnic or racial identiﬁcation may be used if necessary illustrate an instruction that depends upon the use of that name, such as how to construct a Name Control, how to ﬁle records, or how to from a foreign alphabet. d. Any name or address that may be seen as casting reﬂections on the character or behavior of any person or of taxpayers in general, or that may be seen as whimsical or provocative. e. Any name that may be associated with a joke, anecdote, or anagram, could detract from the efficient and businesslike presentation of the mation involved. (

) Names may be selected from a class of objects such as colors, animals, plants, the phonetic alphabet or common natural names such as Brown, Jones, and Smith. Good judgment should be used to avoid objects or nations of objects that might suggest results contrary to the intent of this instruction. (
) Business or corporate names must be similarly selected or constructed, and must avoid any possibility of suggesting to the reader any actual business ganization. (
) City names should similarly be neutral such as “Anytown,” or use the name a major city having no unfavorable connotations in relation to the materials Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

, Physical Security Program. “Official Use Only” material, although not available to the public, may neverthe- less have wide distribution within the IRS. Return information and taxpayer identities should only be distributed to individuals with a valid business need to know as deﬁned in IRC §

requires disclosure to the public in an elec- tronic form. This provision of the law requiring electronic disclosure is to as the Electronic Freedom of Information Act (E-FOIA). Staff (

The FOIA as amended in
requires disclosure to the public in an elec- tronic form. This provision of the law requiring electronic disclosure is referred to as the Electronic Freedom of Information Act (E-FOIA).
Note: Official Use Only (OUO) information is removed from posted materials as exempt from public disclosure under
USC

(09-28-2018) Complying with FOIA Requirements for Instructions to Staff
SPDER posts recently issued Policy Statements and Servicewide Delegation Orders not yet incorporated into the IRM to the FOIA Library on IRS.gov.

a. The guidance is procedural and communicates direction, guidelines, standards to employees in the performance of their assigned duties. b. The guidance affects how a member of the public ﬁles, pays, with their tax requirements, or interacts with the Service. c. The guidance is not exempt from disclosure under
USC
